Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assessing Drivers of Climate Model Biases on the Pacific Continental Shelf of Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oceanographic processes in the Pacific sector of coastal Antarctica exhibit global interactions, including contribution of Antarctic ice-sheets to sea level rise, changes in the Earth's radiative balance, air/sea gas exchange through sea-ice variability, deep water formation, and Southern Ocean biological productivity. Atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (GCMs) are useful tools for understanding the complex interactions between global climate, the Antarctic coastal ocean, the cryosphere (sea ice, ice shelves, and grounded, marine-based ice sheet), and Antarctic ecosystems.

Current-generation GCMs exhibit substantial biases in their projections of present-day hydrography and sea ice state. Previous projections of the coastal cryosphere have applied simple bias corrections. However, this approach does not remedy the underlying physical and numerical errors responsible for these biases. This project seeks the relevance of biases to the interpretation of GCM projections by identifying their local and/or remote origins and their variation across regions and with different climate models. It will leverage the wealth of new simulations becoming available through the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project, phase 6 (CMIP6), and will focus on the rapidly-changing Pacific sector of the coastal Antarctic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project continues to extend the scientific understanding of Antarctic Continental Shelf (ACS) hydrography through the improvement of observational datasets and the evaluation of climate models. Major thrusts include the development of interpolation techniques that account for spatio-temporal sparsity and measurement uncertainties on the ACS, and the distribution of new gridded observational products that incorporate these techniques. The project has developed and tested alternative approaches for model-data comparison that are less reliant upon interpolation methods. Using both alternative and traditional (gridded) model-data comparison techniques, the project has assessed hydrographic biases and underlying physical processes in state-of-the-art climate and ocean models. Ongoing efforts are focused on finalizing and distributing datasets and performing a broad evaluation of the mean ACS state across all available CMIP6 (Climate Model Intercomparison Project, Phase 6) simulations.

Related analyses have been utilized by an extensive network of collaborators in several international efforts, including the ice sheet model intercomparison project (ISMIP6). Through ISMIP6, analyses and datasets developed in the course of this project have been used to drive climate model evaluation efforts and sea level projections from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets (including those contained in the upcoming Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Sixth Assessment Report). Through this report, other publications, and the involvement of project PIs in local adaptation efforts, this project will: (1) provide information to planners and policy-makers seeking to minimize the adverse consequences to people affected by sea-level change, and (2) set the stage for improved projections from future climate model ensembles.

Over the course of this two-year project, researchers at AER were coauthors on seven peer-reviewed papers, many of which have been presented by the lead authors at international conferences. Several additional papers are in preparation. The project supported the training of a junior scientist at AER and facilitated the involvement of PI Little in several domestic international collaborations, workshops, and working groups. Related interactions have led to new, complementary, research efforts in climate and related ice-ocean and sea level variability, including a project funded through the NSF Navigating the New Arctic program to identify the influence of climate change on local communities and ecosystems.
